smell_analysis.justification: No empty diagrams were found; each page that appears to be a diagram contains named elements (e.g., use cases on pages 2-3, activity actions on page 4, classes/tables on pages 5-8 and 10-19, states on page 9).

On the use case diagrams (pages 2 and 3), actors and use cases are listed, but the PDF text does not explicitly show which ovals are or are not associated with actors; no unambiguous unassociated use case is directly visible. The text lists inside the overview/package-like diagram on page 1 are not evaluated for this rule.

Across the use case diagrams, no two or more use cases with clearly synonymous names associated with the same actor are explicitly visible. The names such as 'Registreeri auto', 'Lõpeta auto', 'Muuda autot', and 'Aktiveeri auto' appear to describe distinct activities.

On the package-like diagram on page 1, there is no explicit repetition of the same primary element name within the same package list. Repeated classifier-type or 'from' annotations are treated as metadata and do not indicate duplicate model elements.

The database-style diagrams (pages 14-19) show standard FK relationships and common system-like columns. No explicit case is visible where the same data value is duplicated across tables without a foreign key connecting them. Identically named generic fields are not sufficient evidence of redundancy.

The use case diagram on page 2 mixes naming forms: several use cases start with active verbs (e.g., 'Tuvasta kasutaja', 'Vaata kõiki autosid', 'Vaata autode koondaruannet') while 'Aktiivsed autod' appears as a noun/adjective phrase. This is an explicit inconsistent form within the same diagram.

In the state diagram on page 9, states such as 'Ootel', 'Aktiivne', 'Mitteaktiivne', 'Lõpetatud', and 'Unustatud' are shown, but the PDF does not provide explicit evidence that any state is unreachable. Without an unambiguous unreachable indication, this rule is not triggered.
The activity diagram on page 4 shows a connected flow with actions like 'Otsi autot', 'Vali auto', and 'Lõpeta valitud auto'. No action is explicitly shown as unreachable.

Class-style diagrams display multiplicities where visible (e.g., page 5 and page 10 show '1', '0..*', '0..1'). The database-style diagrams use FK connectors and related notation, which are exempt from this rule even if explicit UML multiplicity labels are not printed. No UML-style relationship lacking multiplicities at both ends is explicitly visible.

No single diagram clearly shows 10 or more central elements. For example, page 2 appears to have 4 use cases, page 3 about 7 use cases, page 9 about 5 main states, and the class/DB diagrams appear to show fewer than 10 central classes/tables each. Actors and overview/context elements are not counted.

The PDF text does not unambiguously show any single class/table on a single diagram with 6 or more distinct, separately drawn visible relationship lines. Without clear visual evidence of that number of separate connectors, this rule is not triggered.

This rule depends on relative visual distances between related elements. The provided PDF text does not make such distances explicit, and no unambiguous long-distance relationship exceeding the stated threshold is directly visible.

The use case 'Aktiivsed autod' on page 2 does not start with an active verb, while other use cases on that diagram do. This is an explicit violation for a use case name. The activity actions on page 4 appear to start with verbs.
No class, table, attribute, state, or use case name of 3 or fewer characters is clearly visible. Names like 'Isik', 'Auto', 'Riik', and 'Klient' are longer than 3 characters.

No class name is clearly shown starting with a lowercase letter or being plural for a singular domain object. The main entity classes such as 'Isik', 'Töötaja', 'Auto', and 'Klient' appear singular and capitalized. Plural register labels are not treated as violations per the interpretation rules.

Attribute and column names shown in class and database diagrams appear to start with lowercase letters (e.g., 'eesnimi', 'perenimi', 'reg_aeg', 'vin_kood', 'on_aktiivne'). No explicit attribute/column name starting with an uppercase letter is visible.

Database table names visible on pages 14-19 appear singular (e.g., 'Isik', 'Kasutajakonto', 'Auto', 'Klient', 'Riik', 'Auto_mark'). No clearly plural table name representing a singular domain object is visible.

No class, table, or attribute names with type-indicating prefixes such as 'tbl_', 'uc_', or 'str' are clearly visible. Allowed prefixes like 'PK_', 'FK_', 'pfK_', and 'IXFK_' appear only as constraint/index annotations in the database diagrams and are explicitly permitted.
